description: Rigid body kinematics; Newtonian formulations of laws of motion; concepts of momentum, energy and inertia properties; generalized coordinates, holonomic and nonholonomic constraints. Generalized forces, principle of virtual work, D'Alembert's principle. Lagrange's equations of motion and Hamilton's equations. Conservation laws and integrals of motion. Friction, impulsive forces and impact. Applications to systems of rigid bodies.
name: ADVANCED DYNAMICS

values.comments:
This course covers a wide range of topics related to advanced dynamics, including
rigid body kinematics; Newton formulations of laws of motion; concepts of momentum,
energy and inertia properties; generalized coordinates, holonomic and nonholonomic
constraints. Other topics are generalized forces, principle of virtual work, D'Alembert's
principle, Lagrange's equations of motion, Hamilton's equations, conservation laws,
integrals of motion, friction, impulsive forces and impact, and applications to systems of
rigid bodies.
Many students gave positive comments on this course, indicating that it was “very
practical,” “challenging but useful,” and “educative and engaging.” Some noted, “the
progression of the material and the scope of the course are both well designed.” One
student found it “an interesting and fun course especially for people interested in viewing
things intuitively.” However, students generally hoped to have “a more consistent
system” featuring only one instructor rather than two.
Students considered the notes written by Professor Kumar as “very helpful and
tremendously worth taking the time to read,” but hoped the solutions to the homework
questions could be thoroughly explained.
The amount of the homework was highly unpredictable and the homework
grading “seemed inconsistent and very unhelpful.” However, students found the test
grading to be fair. This is a graduate level course and is open to all engineering graduate
students. Students are expected to have a basic background in physics.
